section.title: whoami
section.para: The whoamiwhoami(1) command exists to tell you your username.
section.screen: [root@RHEL5 ~]# whoami root [root@RHEL5 ~]# su - paul [paul@RHEL5 ~]$ whoami paul

section.title: who
section.para: The whowho(1) command will give you information about who is logged on to the system.

section.title: who am i
section.para: With who am iwho am i the who command will display only the line pointing to your current session.

section.title: id
section.para: The idid(1) command will give you your user id, primary group id and a list of the groups that you belong to.
section.screen: root@laika:~# id uid=0(root) gid=0(root) groups=0(root) root@laika:~# su - brel brel@laika:~$ id uid=1001(brel) gid=1001(brel) groups=1001(brel),1008(chanson),11578(wolf)

section.title: chsh
section.para: Users can change their own login shell with the chshchsh(1) command. Harry here is first obtaining a list of available shells ( the user could have done a cat /etc/shells/etc/shells ) and then changes his login shell to the Korn shellKorn Shell (/bin/ksh). At the next login, Harry will default into ksh instead of bash.
section.screen: [Harry@RHEL4 ~]$ chsh -l /bin/sh /bin/bash /sbin/nologin /bin/ash /bin/bsh /bin/ksh /usr/bin/ksh /usr/bin/pdksh /bin/tcsh /bin/csh /bin/zsh [Harry@RHEL4 ~]$ chsh -s /bin/ksh Changing shell for Harry. Password: Shell changed. [Harry@RHEL4 ~]$
